This document explains the structure of PAMR-generated regrid scripts.
Consider the sample script generated by PAMR, which used max_lev:=3:

========================================================================

Regrid:t=0.000000,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2
0.000000,3,3,2
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.976562500000000,  -18.632812500000000,  -11.250000000000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.976562500000000,   11.250000000000000,   18.632812500000000
Regrid:t=0.585938,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2
0.585938,3,3,2
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,  -17.812500000000000,  -11.250000000000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,   11.250000000000000,   17.812500000000000
Regrid:t=1.171875,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2
1.171875,3,3,2
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,  -17.226562500000000,  -10.781250000000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,   10.781250000000000,   17.226562500000000
Regrid:t=1.757812,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2
1.757812,3,3,2
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,  -17.343750000000000,  -10.195312500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,   10.195312500000000,   17.343750000000000
Regrid:t=2.343750,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2
2.343750,3,3,2
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,  -17.695312500000000,   -9.726562500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.742187500000000,    9.726562500000000,   17.695312500000000

.
.
.

Regrid:t=4.687500,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2
4.687500,3,3,2
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,  -19.570312500000000,   -7.617187500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,    7.617187500000000,   19.570312500000000
Regrid:t=5.273438,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=4
5.273438,3,3,4
3,    0.000000000000000,    1.289062500000000,  -20.039062500000000,  -14.882812500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,  -13.593750000000000,   -7.148437500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,    7.148437500000000,   13.593750000000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    1.289062500000000,   14.882812500000000,   20.039062500000000
Regrid:t=5.859375,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=4
5.859375,3,3,4
3,    0.000000000000000,    1.289062500000000,  -20.507812500000000,  -15.820312500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,  -13.007812500000000,   -6.562500000000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,    6.562500000000000,   13.007812500000000
3,    0.000000000000000,    1.289062500000000,   15.820312500000000,   20.507812500000000

========================================================================

Each regridding event starts with a line such as

> Regrid:t=0.000000,L1=3,Lf=3,gnum=2

This indicates the time of the regrid, the coarsest level over which the
heirarchy can change, the finest level of the new hierarchy, and the
number of bounding boxes.

The second line is just a repetition of the first in a more
PAMR-readable format:

> 0.000000,3,3,2

The next lines specify the specific coordinate boundaries that the
new bounding boxes should have after the regrid:

> 3,    0.000000000000000,    5.976562500000000,  -18.632812500000000,  -11.250000000000000
  3,    0.000000000000000,    5.976562500000000,   11.250000000000000,   18.632812500000000

The format goes (using a 2D grid in the above example):

[level # on which to regrid], [xmin boundary], [xmax boundary], [ymin boundary], [ymax boundary]

The number of lines indicates how many child grids are to be initialized
at each regrid time. For example, at t=0.0000000 there are only two
lines, so there will be only two child grids initialized on top of the
parent (coarsest) grid. However, at t=5.273438 there will be 4 child
grids present after the regrid:

> 3,    0.000000000000000,    1.289062500000000,  -20.039062500000000,  -14.882812500000000
  3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,  -13.593750000000000,   -7.148437500000000
  3,    0.000000000000000,    5.625000000000000,    7.148437500000000,   13.593750000000000
  3,    0.000000000000000,    1.289062500000000,   14.882812500000000,   20.039062500000000
